chapter.title: Introduction
chapter.para: JBoss BAM is a framework for providing a Business Activity Monitoring solution that integrates with existing JBoss frameworks to retrieve, render and analyze data that empower business knowledge.

section.title: BAM Overview
section.para: The term BAM originally appeared at Gartner, Inc and came from the need of rendering data into valuable real-time information to supervisors, officers and managers of different units within an organization. The main goal of BAM is to provide real-time summary status of different sets of transactions, processes and operations.

Data and analytical information empower all sort of businesses and BAM aims at fortifying the area to enable management layers to derive better informed business decisions, quickly address problem areas, and re-structure their hierarchies to take full advantage of arising opportunities.

section.title: BAM vs BI
section.para: There's more or less a common confusion when it comes to separating BAM (Business Activity Monitoring) from BI (Business Intelligence). This confusion comes from the fact the the roots of the two technologies come from the same background, however the application of the two technologies is radically different.

section.title: Real-time Vs Historical
section.para: BAM processes with real-time data while BI handles historical facts. BAM pushes data into display panels or dashboards while BI retrieves data from history. In this context the output of BAM is a dynamic component rendered in a graphical or tabular format indicating the state of the data at the time it was invoked, while the output of BI is a report that describes facts according a specific set of criteria and time frame.

section.title: Dynamic Vs Static
section.para: As stated earlier, BAM highlights actual facts happening in transactions, processes or operational-modes, this fact highlights a new option that interacts dynamically with other components. BAM becomes dynamic in that perspective to integrate with rules engines and trigger actions such as a notification event or a corrective measurement to the activity. For example a BAM query can trigger a notification to the manager if the average number of tasks executed by a single resource is higher than the limit. BAM could take as well corrective measurements such as rolling back a financial transaction if the value of this transaction exceeds the standard quota. On the BI side none of this flexibility is available, BI displays only data that is derived from the database and rendered in electronic or hard copy format. BI provides the layer of analysis of the past to take preventive measurments against tasks in the future.

section.title: JBoss BAM Overview
section.para:
The JBoss BAM solution currently integrates with
JBoss jBPM
. This solution is designed to provide information by directly querying the jBPM database and returning the results in a set of graphical formats.
